`mean` doesn’t support missing values when using the `dims` argument.
`sum` does, but it doesn’t work with `skipmissing`
Doing broadcasted ops on skipmissing’ed matrixes gives back vectors (`e.g. `skipmissing(mymatrix).^2` )

text: I don't think there's much to do about the last one, since `skipmissing(mymatrix)` can't be represented as a matrix in general.

text:
While it can’t, I am entirely sure it  has  to be.
Since it is a lazy type.
can’t `skipmissing(mymatrix).^2` return the same as `skipmissing(mymatrix.^2)` ?
No, those can’t alway  always be commuted. they can in the case of `x.^2`,
But I guess not `ismissing.(skipmissing(mymatrix))`  (that should make a matrix of all missings or falses, where  as pushing it inside is a matrix of trues and falses.)

I think to make it generalise over both those case we can:
 maintain a mask array from its original state, apply the operation to the inner matrix, then use that mask array to reinsert the missings, and then rewrap in `skipmissing`?
Such that it looks like we still skipped operating on elements that were missing.

text:
idk, my initial code was
```l2_norms = sqrt.(dropdims(mean(data.^2, dims=1), dims=1))```
(itself a hack around `norm` not supporting a `dims` kwarg but i have an issue open for that)
after thinking carefully about the greater context of the algorithm i concluded in this case it was actually correct to just always skipmissings when compute the `l2_norm`
So I did
```data = skipmissings(data)
l2_norms = sqrt.(dropdims(mean(data.^2, dims=1), dims=1))```
as a first thing to check if my logic was correct. (not great since it makes `data` type unstable but that is another discussion.
Anyway, that code errored, and because of the 3 points made above,
I ended up havign to do:

```l2_norms = sqrt.(mean.(skipmissing.(eachslice(data.^2; dims=2))))```
Which guess is ok.
